metadata.case_name: Jivrajbhai Ujamshi Sheth & Ors. (Retiring Partners) v. Chintamanrao & Ors. (Remaining Partners)

facts.text: Vrajlal Manilal Company, a firm consisting originally of four partners: Manilal Anandji, Jivrajbhai Ujamshi Sheth, Punjabhai S. Patel, and Chintamanrao, has been doing business of manufacturing bidis at Sagar and Delhi since 1944.
From time to time fresh partnership deeds were executed readjusting shares, admitting new partners.
Manilal Anandji retired from the firm.
Punjabhai S. Patel died.

Fresh deed of partnership executed. Firm consisted of eight partners: Jivraj and his two sons (anna 4/3 share), Chintamanrao and his two sons (anna 7/6 share), two sons of Punjabhai (anna 4/3 share). Included clauses on accounts (para 7), retirement notice (para 12), valuation basis for retiring partner (para 13: goodwill=net profits last 5 years; outstandings=85% book value; stock raw materials=book value to remaining; immoveable=purchase/book value to remaining), arbitration for disputes (para 16).

Jivraj and his two sons (appellants) desired to retire. Deed of reference executed appointing Ambalal Ashabhai, Becharbhai Somabhai, Chaturbhuj Jasani as arbitrators. Recited agreement to take over by remaining five partners. Matters: goodwill/trade mark, property, credits/udhari, dead-stock, stock-in-trade, other matters, P&L, receipts/payments. Firm to continue with remaining five, pay retiring as decided. Powers to call accounts.
Deed of reference modified; parties agreed to sole arbitrator Shri Jasani.

Arbitrator Jasani made award: goodwill entire firm Rs. 32 lakhs (including depreciation/appreciation of property, dead-stock, dues); profits broken period Samvat 2014 to 1958-04-19 Rs. 2,80,000; after personal accounts: Jivraj Rs. 3,46,223.58; Amritlal Rs. 4,04,519.99; Bhagwandas Rs. 3,86,019.14. Ownership assets to remaining partners subject liabilities; retiring not responsible.

Award filed in Court of Additional District Judge, Sagar under s.14(2) Arbitration Act 1940. Chintamanrao and sons applied to set aside on grounds including arbitrator exceeded jurisdiction (included dep/app in goodwill), legal misconduct (admitted statement by Jivraj sons without knowledge/opportunity).
Retiring partners resisted: entitled to more than 32 lakhs; arbitrator did not overstep; statement prepared under directions, assented.
Trial Court (Additional District Judge) upheld objections, set aside award.
High Court (Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur, Misc. Appeal No. 75 of 1961) confirmed on the two objections.
Arbitrator orders: 1958-09-16 directed Chintamanrao file statement immoveable property book value and approximate current value.
Chintamanrao produced statement net profits Samvat 2009-2013 Rs. 21,70,650/10/- as goodwill price; outstandings Rs. 9,16,366; after 15% deduct Rs. 20,33,295/12/9.
Chintamanrao application: book values already in books, no need detailed inspection.
Arbitrator ordered inspection books 1958-12-21.
Chintamanrao objected to producing certain registers/manufacturing accounts as beyond jurisdiction, reopening closed accounts.
Amrat Lal (retiring) applied: arbitrator to scrutinise books for yearly net profits.
Arbitrator directed produce gross/net profits last 5 years etc.
Balance-sheet Ext. A-13 as on 1958-04-16: tangible assets approx equal debts/liabilities.

legal_issues.text: Whether the arbitrator overstepped limits of authority under agreement of reference by fixing Rs. 32 lakhs as value of divisible assets including depreciation and appreciation of property, dead-stock, outstandings, contrary to para 13 of partnership deed.
Whether arbitrator guilty of legal misconduct by admitting statement of account prepared by Jivraj and sons without knowledge/opportunity to other partners.

petitioner_arguments.text: Arbitrator did not overstep jurisdiction; inclusion of depreciation/appreciation not outside terms; 85% outstandings is depreciation; book value includes dep/app if already accounted; arbitrator to interpret agreement; no error on face of award; entitled to more than 32 lakhs.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Para 13 partnership deed; Chempsey Bhara v. Jivraj Balloo; Cruikshank v. Sutherland

petitioner_arguments.text: Statement prepared under arbitrator directions in presence, assented by remaining partners; mere extracts from books.
Remit award to arbitrator u/s 16 Arbitration Act.

respondent_arguments.text: Arbitrator exceeded jurisdiction by including dep/app of property, dead-stock, outstandings in goodwill valuation Rs. 32 lakhs, contrary to mandatory para 13 (goodwill=5 yr net profits; outstandings=85% book; stock/book value to remaining; no discretion).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Paras 4,6,7 deed reference incorporating partnership deed para 13; s.30 Arbitration Act

respondent_arguments.text: Legal misconduct: admitted statement by retiring partners without notice/opportunity.
Tangible assets approx equal debts/liabilities per balance-sheet.

court_reasoning.text: Deed reference incorporated partnership deed; arbitrator bound to follow para 13 strictly ('as far as possible according to...'); no discretion to include dep/app beyond specified (goodwill=5yr net profits only; outstandings 85% book; stock/immoveables book/purchase value to remaining). Arbitrator expressly included dep/app in goodwill Rs.32L, exceeding jurisdiction; not mere error of law/fact, but assumption of non-existent power; impossible to sever.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Arbitrator stated 'Rs. 32 lakhs is value of goodwill... includes depreciation and appreciation of property, dead-stock, dues'; procedure (orders for current values, gross profits) confirms; award liable to set aside u/s 30.

court_reasoning.text: Not necessary to decide second ground (misconduct re statement) as first succeeds.
No remit u/s 16 as not requested below; no supersession u/s 19 requested.
Hidayatullah J concurs: arbitrator exceeded by adding dep/app; not mere interpretation; followed para 13 limits; no remit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Net profits Rs.21.7L; difference not explained by duplicated dep alone.

holdings.text: Arbitrator exceeded jurisdiction by including depreciation and appreciation in goodwill valuation contrary to para 13 of partnership deed incorporated in reference; award set aside u/s 30 Arbitration Act.
No need to decide misconduct ground.
No power/remit exercised as not requested.

precedents_cited.case_name: Cruikshank and others v. Sutherland and others
precedents_cited.relevance: No application as partnership deed specified book values explicitly, unlike silent articles there.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chempsey Bhara and Company v. Jivraj Balloo Spinning and Weaving Company Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Error of law on face of award for set aside; court cannot probe mental process or speculate reasoning.
Account stated for one purpose not for another.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Arbitration Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Filing award; grounds to set aside (exceeding jurisdiction, misconduct); remit; supersession.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed appeal of retiring partners, confirmed High Court and trial court orders setting aside arbitration award on ground arbitrator exceeded jurisdiction by including depreciation and appreciation in goodwill valuation contrary to partnership deed para 13.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs in one set.

key_quotes.text: "I assess the value of the goodwill at Rs. 32 lakhs. This amount includes the depreciation and appreciation of the property, dead-stock and dues to be recovered."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Arbitrator's express statement showing excess of jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: "The arbitrator has in the present case expressly stated in his award that in arriving at his valuation, he has included the depreciation and appreciation of the property, outstandings and dead-stock, and in so doing... the arbitrator has travelled outside his jurisdiction."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "An error in law on the face of the award means... some legal proposition which is the basis of the award and which you can then say is erroneous."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoting Chempsey Bhara on limited grounds for set aside.
